ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned the basics of cancer and discussed the policies and politics in the world of oncology, pretty much exactly what the syllabus says. I also got a lot of practice and experience reading scientific research papers.
I learned about all aspects of the world of cancer.

I gained a deeper understanding about the complexities that exist between cancer and its affect on society. Throughout the course we learned about the past controversies as well as contemporary discussions surrounding cancer's history, its research and treatment, and policies made regarding its treatment.
Knowledge on cancer, both scientific and political levels, perfect balance of both.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: A great balance of learning about science and politics, not really any weaknesses
I thoroughly enjoyed this course. Great guests and class discussion.

Strengths: The course goes over a lot of material on different aspects of cancer, and all of the guest speakers are very interesting and willing to answer questions.

Weaknesses: The quizzes were sometimes a little confusing, as some of the questions were very specific and might not even be a part of the readings that were assigned.

Strengths: 
Prof. Bazell is very knowledgeable and able to explain any and all course material in great detail when confusion arises
Engaging/very relevant guest speakers who are also well versed in the topic
Holistic portrayal of cancer

Weaknesses:
None
Strengths- Small class, great professor, interesting material

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I found the discussions very helpful and there were a limited amount of lectures. I think the breakout rooms were also very effective in discussing the course content.

What succeeded was the level of engagement and discussion in lectures as well as the number of accomplished guest speakers who deepened our understanding of the material - not much could've been improved

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, as a non-science major this was a fun way for me to get a science credit and learned quite a bit.
Yes 100%
Yes! You learn so much about different aspects of cancer, and there are many amazing guest speakers that are very accomplished and can give insight into the fight against cancer.

I would definitely recommend this course to any first year student. The class is extremely enjoyable and gaining a deeper understanding on cancer and the ongoing research and discussions behind it will help any student no matter their major in the years to come.

I would definitely recommend this course to another student - cancer is a very relevant public health issue and I gained a much deeper understanding for the scientific and political aspects of it after taking this course
Yes! My favorite class of my freshman year. Bazell is the best!

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: combination of recorded lectures to watch for homework, then live discussions during class
Some recorded lectures
There were a few live virtual lectures as well.
Virtual first year seminar

extras.title:
MCDB 040 01
        Science and Politics of Cancer
